journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: Vibroacoustics of composite housing for electrical motors

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Advanced Research and Development, ThyssenKrupp Presta, Eschen, Liechtenstein
2Institute of Automotive Engineering, RWTH Aachen University, Aachen, Germany

author-notes.corresp: M Meyer, Department of Advanced Research and Development, ThyssenKrupp Presta, Essanestrasse 10, FL-9492 Eschen, Liechtenstein. Email: martin.meyer2@thyssenkrupp.com

abstract.p: This study is aimed at the specific practicable application of certain composite elements for housing of electrical motors. This article presents a novel analytical model for forced vibrations and vibroacoustic investigations of a laminated shell composed of two metallic layers with a polymeric interlayer. This material composition differs from classical sandwich materials due to the thickness-relations (thickness ratio of cover layer to the interlayer of about 20) as well as jump of stiffness between the single layers (ratio of about 20,000). The dynamic theory of cylindrical shells has been enhanced to include the vibroacoustic behaviour of the composite shell with polymeric interlayer. The results presented in this article include mode shapes and frequency of free vibrations as well as the forced vibrations of composite shell with polymeric interlayer and its monolithic counterpart. The damping values of this structural composition were found to exceed those of a corresponding monolithic metallic shell by a factor of over 100. Moreover, a number of dynamic and vibroacoustic finite element simulations were also carried out whereby close correlation between the analytical models and the numerical finite element results were achieved. Using this composite material, and its related models, a reduction of the transverse vibration amplitude by a factor of 10 compared to the monolithic material is obtained. The results of this article can be an effective tool for the vibroacoustic analysis and design of electrical motor housings.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The automotive industry increasingly faces a new challenge of substitution of classical mechanical, hydraulic or combustion systems by electrical motors (EMs). In this connection, the electromechanical elements provide a main contribution to the improved acoustical characteristics of modern transport systems. The impact of these new drive concepts on the sound radiation is not yet profoundly explored by the design engineers.

In addition to structural requirements, high vibration and acoustic damping are considered two essential requirements for the housing of EMs. The classical single layer metallic cylindrical shells come short in fulfilling all these requirements. To overcome these shortcomings, a new concept is explored and a series of engineering investigations reported herein are carried out. The proposed composite material consists of two metallic layers with a polymeric interlayer. This article studies the concept of using a multilayer composite material with unusual characteristics and presents a novel analytical modelling approach for vibroacoustic investigations of cylindrical shells made of three-layer composite.

The main contributions of this article include:
A novel analytical modelling for vibroacoustic investigations of a laminated cylindrical shell made of metallic layers with polymeric interlayer is developed. The coupled shell theory of cylindrical shells has been modified and enhanced to include the vibroacoustic behaviour of the composite shell with polymeric interlayer.
The dynamic properties of the composite shells made of the aforementioned laminate are investigated by means of analytical and numerical finite element (FE) methods. Moreover, the damping characteristics and stiffness are experimentally obtained and are correlated with the theoretical results.
The practicable application of special laminated material for the EM housing is explored. Comparison is made with a monolithic element of similar dimensions. It is shown that by employing the new material, and the corresponding theoretical design, a reduction of the vibration amplitude by the factor of 10 and an increase of the damping loss up to a factor of 100 can be achieved.
The investigations carried out in this article prove to be of interest to those dealing with noise vibration and harshness issues.

Literary articles are already available that basically concentrate on the vibration behaviour of sandwich and laminate structures. In 1960s, Ungar, Ross and Kerwin investigated the system damping of sandwich structures.1–3 A further increase of accuracy of the models was achieved by Rao4,5 and Mead.6 Studies of the laminate behaviour in different structure assemblies like unsymmetrical layer-thickness were reviewed.7 The application to the plate geometry has been investigated in a number of papers, especially with focus on active damping capabilities.8–10 Nakra11 also dealt with the formulation of the dynamic mechanical behaviour of laminate beams and pointed out that the investigation of noise radiation of such structures is still an open issue. Few releases still exist in the field of vibration modelling of thin composite cylindrical shells. Pan12 developed a model based on the consideration of force equilibrium regarding the shear effects in the composite. Markus13,14 dealt with the analysis of vibrations of layered unconstrained cylindrical shells. Vibration and damping analysis of constrained layer laminate cylindrical shell structures have been accomplished in few papers.15–19 Sound radiation has been considered in some publications for cylindrical geometries. The aviation industry has a special interest on this, in which mainly sound transmission effects from the engines to the interior have been investigated. Fuller20 and other authors reviewed this issue in a number of papers.21,22

In regard to the referred literature, this article offers a first comprehensive investigation of the combined vibration and acoustical behaviour of a laminated shell structure used as an EM housing. Material investigations have been conducted to determine input parameters for a latter vibration model. The results of the material analysis are presented in this article in the section ‘Material and structure of new housing for EM’. Following this, a dynamic mechanical model of a damped laminate structure is set up and verified by FE simulation results in the section ‘Vibration behaviour of cylindrical EM housing’. Based on these results an acoustical radiation model of the cylindrical body is created and repeatedly validated with results of the numerical simulation in the section ‘Vibroacoustical behaviour of cylindrical EM housing’. Finally, the ‘Discussion of results’ on some vibroacoustical features of the constrained structure is given, followed by the ‘Conclusion’.

sec.title: Material and structure of new housing for EMs
Description
sec.p: The investigation of the substitution of a standard EM housing by a non-homogeneous multilayer shallow body is in the scope of this article. The requirements on the housing are manifold, as to provide a certain amount of static stiffness and also to carry damping properties to reduce the motor structure vibration. The bending vibrations are responsible for the acoustical radiation of the EM during operation and thus the housing has a major impact on the acoustical performance.

Available systems consist of a monolithic housing made of isotropic material like steel or aluminium, enclosing the physical body of the motor. Sometimes the housing is manufactured of cast iron for giving some specific topography. The advantage of using a sandwich-like material is to combine specific features of each material in a composite nature. Namely the poor damping properties of a monolithic steel body could be improved by inserting a core layer of a polymeric material. The observed structure in this article cannot be described as a classical sandwich and thus the classical theories like Euler–Bernoulli23 or Timoshenko24 cannot be applied. The reason is the assembly of the laminate body, depicted in Figure 9, and its material selection.

The core layer is constrained by two cover layers with thicknesses d1 and d3. The thickness relation between cover and core layer reaches initially a value of d1: d2 > 20 and hence exactly vice versa to a classical sandwich. The material composition is quite heterogeneous with stiffness jumps in radial direction. This constellation creates different vibration patterns in the core and cover layers. While the cover layers are subjected to bending vibration, shear strain is induced in the core layer. Even a small radial displacement of bending vibration results in huge shear deformation in the core due to the layer’s thickness relation. Thus the damping mechanisms are activated very efficiently.

sec.title: Material characterization of laminate with polymeric interlayer
sec.p: For a proper manufacturing and optimization of the product performance a detailed experimental and theoretical materials characterization of the interlayer polymer is required. For this purpose, a dynamic mechanical thermal analysis experimental methodology (DMTA) is employed. The DMTA testing method uses the material samples under various temperature conditions subjected to low frequency cycling shear force. The upper frequency limit of this test is 100 Hz. The DMTA testing of samples take place in chamber with controlled temperature conditions. The DMTA test results complex values of shear modulus taking in account the linear viscoelastic behaviour of the material. The details of DMTA testing process are outlined in ISO 6721-1:2001.25

Tables 1 and 2 present the frequency and the temperature dependent real part of the shear modulus and the corresponding loss factor. Table 1.
Shear modulus from material tests.
Shear modulus G of interlayer (MPa)
Temperature (°C) Frequency (Hz)
1 10 25 50 100
−20 18.9 24.8 28.0 29.4 30.8
25 2.2 3.5 5.5 6.5 7.0
60 1.3 1.4 1.8 2.3 2.7
Table 2.
Loss factor from material tests.
Loss factor η of interlayer
Temperature (°C) Frequency (Hz)
1 10 25 50 100
−20 0.21 0.30 0.34 0.38 0.5
25 0.42 0.46 0.45 0.45 0.47
60 0.36 0.54 0.60 0.67 0.71
In passing, it is observed that the stiffness of the polymeric core is about 20,000 times less than of steel while its damping parameter is more than 500 times higher than the metallic counterpart.

sec.title: Vibration behaviour of cylindrical EM housing
Analytical modelling of cylindrical EM housing
sec.p: The classical and non-classical dynamical theories of shells have been treated in various literature.24,26,27 One of the classical shell theories related to the dynamic of cylindrical shells is referred to as the Donell and Mushtari theory.28 In this article, the cylindrical shell theory is extended for the investigation of a laminated cylindrical EM housing (Figure 10). For theoretical investigations, simply supported boundary conditions are assumed.
The damping factor is considered as a frequency independent material parameter, represented by a complex shear modulus G. This assumption is based on the experimental material characterization.

The Donell–Mushtari differential equations28 are generalized to take into account the multi-layer character of the shell with additional material damping. For this purpose, the differential equations for individual layers (i = 1, 2, 3) are added to each other in a conforming fashion. Consequently, the differential equations of dynamic response of the three-layer cylindrical shell with polymeric interlayer can be written as follows (1)d1dT·{a2·∂2u1∂x2+0.5·(1-μ1)·a2·∂2u1∂β2+0.5·(1+μ1)·a·∂2v1∂x∂β+μ1·a·∂w1∂x-a2·ρ·(d1s1)·∂2u1∂t2} +d3dT·{a2·∂2u3∂x2+0.5·(1-μ3)·a2·∂2u3∂β2+0.5·(1+μ3)·a·∂2v3∂x∂β+μ3·a·∂w3∂x-a2·ρ·(d3s3)·∂2u3∂t2}=0 (2)d1dT·{0.5·(1+μ1)·a·∂2u1∂x∂β+∂2v1∂β2+0.5·(1-μ1)·a2·∂2v1∂x2+∂w1∂β-a2·ρ·(d1s1)·∂2v1∂t2} +d3dT·{0.5·(1+μ3)·a·∂2u3∂x∂β+∂2v3∂β2+0.5·(1-μ3)·a2·∂2v3∂x2+∂w3∂β-a2·ρ·(d3s3)·∂2v3∂t2}=0 (3)d1dT·{μ1·a·∂u1∂x+∂v1∂β+w1+r1·(a4·∂4w1∂x4+2·a2·∂4w1∂x2∂β2+∂4w1∂β4)-a2·ρ·(d1s1)·∂2w1∂t2+G22·d2·(d12s1)·(a2·∂2w1∂x2+∂2w1∂β2)} +d3dT·{μ3·a·∂u3∂x+∂v3∂β+w3+r3·(a4·∂4w3∂x4+2·a2·∂4w3∂x2∂β2+∂4w3∂β4)-a2·ρ·(d3s3)·∂2w3∂t2+G22·d2·(d32s3)·(a2·∂2w3∂x2+∂2w3∂β2)}=a2s·q The symbols used in the above equations are defined at the end of this article. Moreover dT denotes the sum thickness of the top layers d1, d3 and the two parameters s and r are defined by the following expressions (4)ri=di212·a2 (5)si=E·di1-μ2

In the following, the dynamic response of the laminated shell subjected to a harmonic excitation q (x, β, t) shall be investigated. The forcing function is assumed to be of the following general form (6)q(x,β,t)=Q(x,β)·sin(Ωt)

The steady-state dynamic response of cylindrical shells, expressed as components of the displacement of the middle surface (u, v, w) can be written in the form of the following harmonic expansions28 (7)ui(x,Θ,t)=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞[Um,n(t)·cos(m·Θ)·cos(n·π·xL)]=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Um,n(t)·u~m,n(x,Θ) (8)vi(x,Θ,t)=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞[Vm,n(t)·sin(m·Θ)·sin(n·π·xL)]=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Vm,n(t)·v~m,n(x,Θ) (9)wi(x,Θ,t)=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞[Wm,n(t)·cos(m·Θ)·sin(n·π·xL)]=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Wm,n(t)·w~m,n(x,Θ) where i = 1, 2, 3. The modal wave numbers in axial and circumferential direction are given by n and m, respectively. Using the orthogonality relation of the modes, one can express the forced response equation of the laminate cylinder as follows (10)Wm,n(t)=Cm,n·sin(Ωt-ϕ) (11)Cm,n=Am,n2+Bm,n2 (12)ϕ=arctan(Bm,nAm,n)
The functions Am, n and Bm, n appearing in the above expressions have the following definitions (13)Am,n=|-a2s·Qm,n·a3,22*Δm,n| (14)Bm,n=|a3,21*·a2s·Qm,nΔm,n| (15)Δm,n=a3,11*·a3,22*-a3,21*·a3,12*
The expressions for the parameters ai, j can be found in the Appendix.

As a specific case of excitation, we consider the forcing function consist of a single harmonic force acting in the middle of the cylinder. This excitation can be expressed as (16)Qm,n=∫x=0L∫Θ=02π{Q0·δ(x-x0)·δ(Θ-Θ0)·cos(m·Θ)·sin(n·π·xL)}dxdΘ=Q0·sin(n·π·x0L)·cos(m·Θ0)
Incorporating this load leads to the following expression for the steady-state response of the laminate cylinder in the radial direction (17)w(x,Θ,t)=∑m=1∞∑n=1∞Cm,n·cos(m·Θ)·sin(n·π·xL) ·sin(Ωt-ϕ)

sec.title: Results of analytical and numerical modelling
sec.p:
A comparison of the forced response of a simple monolithic steel housing and a laminated housing is accomplished in Figure 11, applying the derived analytical algorithm and the material data from Table 3. Table 3.
Material parameters.
MaterialSteelPolymer
Density ρ (kg/m3) 7.85 E + 003 1.04 E + 003
Young’s modulus E (N/m2) 2.1 E + 011
Shear modulus G (N/m2)
1.0 E + 007
Loss factor η 1 E − 004 6 E − 001
Obviously the mode with the lowest resonance frequency is the (m, n) = (3, 1) mode. A frequency analysis for the monolithic and the laminated shell proves this statement.

A correlation analysis between analytical and numerical results of free and forced vibrations serves as validation of the analytical model. The correlation is displayed for two criteria which are the resonance frequency and the amplitude of the forced steady-state response for each mode. The correspondence for the monolithic cylinder housing is displayed below in Figures 1 and 2 where the dots depict the correlation between the analytical and the numerical results. Figure 1.
Correlation of the vibration amplitude from analytical and numerical solutions for a monolithic and stacked steel housing. Figure 2.
Correlation of the natural frequencies from analytical and numerical solutions for a monolithic and stacked steel housing.

This result is based on the correlation of analytical results with a FE simulation. The resonance frequencies show a general agreement. For higher modes, the amplitude of the FE model tends to be lower than the one of the analytical model which is comprehensible because a FE calculation is usually expected to predict an upper bound to the stiffness of the system. The damping, which is responsible for the modal amplitude, seems to be defined properly.

A very special situation, also considered here, would be the case of a stacked shell, i.e. a shell with totally unattached friction-free layers with two loose steel layers lying on each other (Figure 3). Figure 3.
Stacked two-layer cylinder.

The material data of the foregoing analysis is used here. The damping of the steel layers has a homogeneous influence on all modes as demonstrated. For the laminate, the global damping is controlled by two factors, the homogeneous damping of the cover layers and the activation of damping in the core layer. Considering the results, the response amplitude deviates relatively to the ideal correlation in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Correlation of the vibration amplitude from analytical and numerical solutions for a laminated housing.

We evaluate if this deviation derives from some shortcomings from the FE model. To overcome these shortcomings, calculations are also made using the so-called linearized spring model and the fully solid model. The spring model is the one in which two outer layers of the shell are connected with each other with linear spring elements having the properties of the interlayer. The fully solid model uses solid elements for all layers of the laminate shell. We find that the relative correlation to the analytical results is improved using the solid model instead of the spring model. This verifies that the FE model itself has an impact on the absolute correlation quality, which is not negligible. So we can conclude that the correlation under these boundary conditions is fairly well and the analytical model works properly. This can be underlined by a qualitative observation of the damping behaviour. Some modes are much more concerned with damping than others which can be found from the response function of the laminate cylinder. This derives from the formulation of the damping activation. In consequence, modes with a higher curvature, like higher order modes, activate damping more efficiently. This result can also be found from the FE results and is hence a good remark on the quality of the analytical model. Additionally the resonance frequencies in Figure 5 also deliver a fairly good correlation. Figure 5.
Correlation of the natural frequencies from analytical and numerical solutions for a laminated housing.

sec.title: Vibroacoustical behaviour of cylindrical EM housing
Analytical modelling
sec.p: With the verified dynamic model we can develop a holistic vibroacoustical investigation tool by including the calculation of the acoustical radiation from the vibrating shell. Therefore, a radiation model is being set up and investigated for a proper functionality. The created analytical expression should be correlated to numerical results afterwards.

We apply cylindrical waves (review Figure 12) to create a radiation model because this involves very similar conditions to plane waves where a lot of formulations already exist. Fundamental work on this topic can be found in Williams.29
The radiated sound pressure can be abstracted by a separation of variables (18)p(x,ϕ,r,t)=X(x)·Φ(ϕ)·R(r)·T(t)

For the succeeding inspection, we first transform this expression into the wavenumber domain and use the so-called Hankel function to approximate the decay of pressure over distance.29 The Hankel function has the property of being infinity in the origin of the coordinate system and a decaying character as a function of radial distance (19)p(x,ϕ,r,ω)=∑m=-∞∞eimϕ·12·π·∫-∞∞Am(kx,ω)·eikxx · Hm(1)(kr·r)dkx here kx and kr denote the circular wavenumbers in axial and radial directions, respectively and Am is a placeholder for X(x) and Φ(φ). The solution for Am can be derived by calculating the pressure for two different positions in space, a and r where r > a must be satisfied. The integral expression can be eliminated by employing the Fourier transformation of the sound pressure and its reverse transformation (20)Pm(r,kx)=12·π·∫02πdϕ ∫-∞∞p(x,ϕ,r)·e-imϕ·e-ikxxdx (21)p(x,ϕ,r,ω)=∑m=-∞∞eimϕ·12·π·∫-∞∞Pm(r,kx)·eikxxdkx
Hence we receive an expression for the relation of the transformed pressure at two different positions in space (22)Pm(r,kx)=Pm(a,kx)·Hm(1)(kr·r)Hm(1)(kr·a)

Using the Helmholtz formulation and the condition of continuity, a relation between the surface velocity and the pressure in the surrounding fluid can be derived in the wave number space (23)W·(a,kx)=-iρL·cL·kL·∂∂rPm(a,kx)
A relation of the transformed surface velocity and pressure in distance r can be received applying the foregoing formalism (24)W·(a,kx)=-iρL·cL·kL·kr·Hm(kr·a)Hm(1)(kr·r)·Pm(r,kx)

The subscript L represents the surrounding fluid whereas x and r denote propagation in axial and radial directions, respectively. Including this formulation into the initial pressure formulation, results in the following expression (25)p(x,ϕ,r)=i·ρL·cL·kL2·π·∑m=-∞∞eimϕ·∫-∞∞Hm(1)(kr·r)kr·Hm(kr·a) ·W·(a,kx)·eikxxdkx

Finally, the velocity term needs to be retransformed into the domain of geometrical dimensions. The problem of solving the integral expressions can be avoided by reducing the complexity by the assumption that axial waves are negligible. Thus, kx = 0 which is not a significant deviation from the regarded case where the mode shape in axial direction actually is a half sine. Thus, the velocity expression can be replaced by a median in axial direction with w∧ means the radial vibration amplitude (26)·¯w=1L·∫0L2·π·w∧·cos(mϕ) ·sin(n·π·xL)dx=4·w∧·cos(mϕ) n=1

Inserting this relation and incorporating the delta Dirac function, results in a formulation for the transformed surface velocity. Applying the following relations (27)kL=kr (28)eikxx=1 (29)∫-∞∞δ(kx)·f(x)dkz=f(x)
The final expression for the radiated sound pressure is derived in the desired form (30)p(x,ϕ,r)=i·ρL·cL2·π·∑m=-∞∞eimϕ·(4·π·m+i·(e-i4πm-1)m) · f·w∧·Hm(1)(k·r)Hm(k·a)

sec.title: Results of vibroacoustical modelling
sec.p:
The results of the analytical and the numerical calculation of the boundary element (BE) model are compared to inspect the functionality of the analytical radiation model. The characteristic of the frequency spectra is dominated by some significant modes. The shape of this characteristic is quite similar for both approaches. Hence a qualitative correlation of the analytical results to the BE simulation results is found. Nevertheless, one can find from Figure 6 a gap of the values especially in the frequency range below the first appearing natural frequency. This area is dominated by the so-called acoustical shunt effects which seem to be less regarded in the analytical expression. The shunt effect can be described as a phenomenon in which the pressure balance between two sides creates a situation in which no wave propagation takes place. Except the shunt effect area, the amplitudes fit quite well. Hence a quantitative correlation can be observed which is not as refined as the qualitative but is still within an acceptable range. The pressure level amplitude defers less than 4 dB when the frequency shift is taken into account. This difference is an accumulation of all effects in the whole calculation line including the differences in the structure-dynamic calculation, demonstrated before. Figure 6.
Results for sound pressure level of a laminated cylindrical housing from analytical and numerical calculations.

sec.title: Discussion of results
sec.p:
The material data of the polymeric interlayer had to be investigated as a fundament for the vibroacoustical discussion of a laminate housing concept of an EM. The DMTA method was applied to determine stiffness and damping values over a dynamic range under different temperature conditions for a stress situation which comes close to the real one in the laminate subjected to bending. The loss factor was found to be slightly dependent to frequency with increasing values for higher frequency. The value of the loss factor depends also on the temperature but with a quite low gradient. The deformation in the interlayer is dominated by shear effects, thus the shear module is the relevant parameter to evaluate the stiffness. The shear module has a much more significant dependence on frequency and temperature than the loss factor. In the investigated range, the module increases over frequency and decreases over temperature. This behaviour is well known as the time-temperature dependence of amorphous materials. Using this relationship, the module can be extrapolated over the investigated frequency range. The following characteristic, displayed in Figure 7 can be obtained that fits excellent to previous investigations on similar materials by Nashif et al.30 Figure 7.
Extrapolated Young’s modulus of the polymeric interlayer material.

The response function of a cylindrical shallow body is calculated applying these material data to the developed vibration model. It turns out that the first appearing natural frequency belongs to the (3, 1) mode as demonstrated before. This is a very important information for the influence of the vibration behaviour under an optimization point of view. It can be observed that the mode shape of the lowest natural frequency can be shifted to lower or higher values by changing the stiffness of the interlayer. The mode shape again also has a major influence on the damping performance of the laminate. In opposite to a monolithic cylinder, where the damping is constantly low over all modes, the damping of the laminate is being activated by the curvature during bending vibration and is thus increased for higher order modes. But the damping activation also depends on the radial displacement during bending. Because the bending amplitude decreases with the increasing mode order a turning point appears, where the global damping of the laminate reaches its maximum. For the investigated constellation of material properties and geometrical dimensions, the maximum global loss factor can be found for the (4, 1) mode as demonstrated in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Global loss factor of the laminated cylindrical housing for the first five circumferential modes. Figure 9.
Assembly of the laminate structure in a cylindrical geometry. Figure 10.
Cylindrical laminated shell housing for an EM.
EM: electrical motor. Figure 11.
Forced response function of a steel cylindrical housing and a laminated cylindrical housing. Figure 12.
Propagation of the cylindrical wave field.

The damping values of the laminate fit to the values achieved from the FE simulation which is at least the background of the satisfying correlation presented in the previous chapters. The employment of the vibration results to the cylindrical radiation model yields results for the emitted sound pressure of the vibrating structure. The short circuit effects in the near field of the vibrating surface are respected in dependence of the mode number. The comparison of the radiated frequency spectra to the results computed with the BE model proves the underrating of those effects by this formulation. Nevertheless a qualitative correlation to the simulation results is detectable and therefore the results are reasonable for a discussion.

The radiation characteristic is controlled by the lower order modes which are purely damped. To improve the radiation image, based on those results different approaches are reliable. One opportunity is to activate damping more efficiently even for the lower order modes. Another procedure is to increase the stiffness and thus the impedance of the structure to reduce the system reaction. A further alternative is to modify the system parameters in a way that the modes are excited in a different sequence. If the system is tuned in a way that higher order modes hold the lowest natural frequency, the activated modes within a certain frequency range could offer a much better damping and thus a reduced radiation.

list-item.p: This article provides an outline of a research on laminate structures applied to a housing construction of an EM with the purpose to enhance its vibroacoustical behaviour. Material properties were determined to create input parameters for a specific vibration model. This model was developed with the focus on a special laminate assembly with extraordinary geometrical relations and remarkable stiffness intersections. The created model has been verified by a validation of natural frequencies and vibration amplitudes under the employment of FE simulation. The correlation of a laminated composite shell produces a satisfying accordance. A qualitative and quantitative correlation could be demonstrated. It could be proved that the FE model itself has some weakness which highlights the demand on a functional and easy manageable analytical model.

A radiation model was designed to calculate the sound pressure emitted from the vibrating structure under some assumptions which are valid for the stated application. Repeatedly, a validation process under the employment of a numerical simulation has been conducted. It proves a reliable qualitative correspondence of the results but even demonstrates some weaknesses of the analytical model. Especially, the short-circuit effects are respected minor which leads to a difference in the pressure level below the first natural frequency of about 8 dB. This difference was also inspected in foregoing researches. However, the results provide some very interesting opportunities to optimize the vibroacoustical performance of a classical monolithic housing by incorporating a laminate structure instead.

The optimization process by the variation of material components and the geometrical composition is the scope of this study on this topic. Further options for an optimization are to modify the stiffness of the cylindrical shell in discrete areas with the knowledge of the vibration pattern at a certain operational point. Another potential can be expected by embedding active materials. By the assignment of electro-active polymers vibration energy could be transformed into electrical energy. The resulting current can be induced into a shunted circuit where the electrical energy is transformed into heat. Also, advanced systems could be created by the implementation of controlled vibration inserts which can be used as a tuned damper under the admission of active vibration energy.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The development and the investigations presented in this paper were funded by ThyssenKrupp AG.

Especially his distinctive expertize in the fields of structural dynamics, shell theory and material science provided a wonderful promotion. The author expresses his appreciation to Dr C Klukowski and the management of ThyssenKrupp for their support of this study. The constructive comments of the referees of this article are also thankfully acknowledged.

RaoDK. Vibrations of short sandwich beams. J Sound Vib 1977; 52(2): 253–263.
RaoDK. Frequency and loss factors of sandwich beams under various boundary conditions. J Mech Eng Sci 1978; 20(5): 271–282.
MeadDJ. A comparison of some equations for the flexural vibration of damped sandwich beams. J Sound Vib 1982; 83(3): 366–377.
FrostigYBaruchMVilneyO. Bending of nonsymmetric sandwich beams with trensversely flexible core. J Eng Mech 1991; 117(9): 1931–1952.
CupialPNiziolJ. Vibration and damping analysis of a three-layered composite plate with a viscoelastic mid-layer. J Sound Vib 1995; 183(1): 99–114.
